questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated, on probation, or parole for a felony of moral turpitude?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include:
  • Murder
  • Manslaughter
  • Assault
  • Sexual assault
  • Sexual abuse of a minor
  • Robbery
  • Arson
  • Burglary
  • Theft
  • Forgery
  • Endangering the welfare of a minor
  • Riot
  • Criminal mischef
  • Misconduct involving a controlled substance
  • Distribution or possession of child pornography
NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

In Alaska, you are eligible to vote.

Register to vote now

label: American Samoa
result:
In American Samoa, there are no restrictions on eligibility to vote based on criminal convictions.

questions.value: Have you ever been charged or convicted of a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result:
In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are eligible to vote. That’s true even if you have been charged with a felony.

Register to vote now

questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated for a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result: In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are eligible to vote. Please request absentee ballot from office administrators at your complex.
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Your right to vote will be restored when you are released from incarceration, even if you are on probation or parole.

In Colorado, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are eligible to vote. That’s true even if you have been charged with a felony.

questions.value: Were you convicted between 1973 and 1981?

options.result:
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Individuals who have been convicted of felonies of moral turputide are eligible to vote only upon completion of their sentence, including probation and parole.

Common felonies of moral turpitude include: murder, manslaughter, assault, sexual assault, sexual abuse of a minor, robery, arson, burglary, theft, forgery, endangering the welfare of a minor, riot, criminal mischef, misconduct involving a controlled substance, and distribution or possession of child pornography.

NOTE: This is not a complete list of felonies of moral turpitude. If you are unsure if your conviction qualifies as a felony of moral turpitude, call or have a friend or family member call 1-866-OUR-VOTE for assistance.

You are eligible to vote.

questions.value: Are you currently incarcerated for a felony or misdemeanor?

options.result: In Utah, no one is disenfranchised for misdemeanors or any convictions other than felonies. If you are incarcerated but have not been convicted of a felony, you are eligible to vote. Please request absentee ballot from office administrators at your complex.
Unfortunately, you are not eligible to vote right now. Your right to vote will be restored when you are released from incarceration, even if you are on probation or parole.

questions.value: Have you completed your sentence for a violent felony, including probation or parole?

options.result:
In Wyoming, people with violent felony convictions are permanently disenfranchised unless they appeal to the governor after a waiting period (5 years for restoration, 10 years for a pardon).

Please apply to your Governor for voting rights restoration.
